In this session we will be discussing the first part of the sixteenth verse of the fifteenth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
The sixteenth verse is as follows.
Yad doshu ma pranihitam guru bhishma karna, naptra trigarta shalya saindhava bahli kaadyai, astrani amogha mahimani nirupitani, nopas prushur nriharidasam ivasurani.
The meaning of this verse is, the sixteenth verse.
Great generals like Bhishma, Drona, Karna, Bhurishrava, Susharma, Shalya, Jayadratha and Balika all directed their invincible weapons against me.
But by his, that is Lord Krishna's grace, they could not even touch a hair on my head.
Similarly, Prahlad Maharaj, the supreme devotee of Lord Nrsimadeva, was unaffected by the weapons the demons used against him.
So Arjuna is telling, because of Lord Krishna's grace, Arjuna was completely protected, that even the powerful Kaurava generals,
they could not touch even one hair of Arjuna.
In a fierce battle like that, how is it that Arjuna escaped completely unhurt, only by the grace of Krishna?
And a comparison is made, just like Prahlad Maharaj was a pure devotee of Lord Nrsimadeva,
and he was unaffected by so much trouble given by,
by,
by the demons, in so many ways, they tried to kill him, but they could not.
Similarly, in the battle of Kurukshetra, the enemy party tried to kill the Pandavas,
but they could not do anything to the Pandavas.

The history of Prahlad Maharaj, the great devotee of Nrsimadeva,

The demon father employed all his weapons to kill the devotee's son, Prahlad,
but by the grace of the Lord,
Prahlad was saved from all the troubles, and he was not killed.

Hiranyakashyapu attempted in so many ways,
let me kill this boy,

Prahlad was perfectly protected by Lord Nrsimadeva directly.

When Duryodhana was in power, he enthroned Karna in the state of Anga.
Being baffled in his attempt to win Draupadi, Karna advised Duryodhana to attack King Drupada, and after defeating him, both Arjuna and Draupadi could be arrested.
But Dronacharya rebuked them for this conspiracy, and they refrained from the action.
Karna was defeated many times, not only by Arjuna, but also by Bhimasena.
He was a king of the kingdom of Bengal, Orissa, and Madras combined.

Later on, Karna took an active part in the Rajasuya sacrifice of Maharaja Yudhishthira, and when there was gambling between the rival brothers designed by Shakuni, Karna took part in the game, and he was very pleased when Draupadi was offered as a bet in the gambling.
That gambling match was ill-fated for the Pandavas.
The Pandavas were losing, and Yudhishthira was placing as a bet even Draupadi, and themselves also as a bet.

at that time, Karna asked Draupadi to select another husband, because she was lost by the Pandavas.

Now Karna maintained enmity against the Pandavas, though they had no reason actually.
Specifically he had no reason, but he maintained his enmity against the Pandavas.
And he tried to curb them by so many ways.
Now during the battle of Kurukshetra,
Now during the battle of Kurukshetra,
he could understand that because Krishna was the chariot driver of Arjuna,
he understood that the Pandavas will win the battle.
And Karna had some difference of opinion on Bhishma,
and sometimes he was very very proud of his prowess,
and he said in his pride,
I can defeat the Pandavas in five days,
if Bhishma would not interfere with my plan of action.
This is the arrogant statement of Karna.
Now when Bhishma died, Karna was very much mortified.
Karna killed the largest number of Pandava soldiers.
When there was a severe fight with Arjuna,
then Karna was able to knock off Arjuna's helmet.
And that's a big achievement because Arjuna was a very very powerful fighter.
Now when Karna was fighting his Arjuna,
his chariot wheel got stuck in the battlefield mud.
And he got down from his chariot to set the wheel right,
but Arjuna took the opportunity and killed Karna

So this is the history of Karna
that's being described by Prabhupada in the Purport.
Karna was a very powerful fighter and Arjuna was able to defeat Karna
